[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: GroupGenerators::default()] [Weak cryptographic parameters] Can an attacker exploit the default group generators if they don't match the protocol's expected generators, potentially allowing them to create invalid proofs or signatures that still verify? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Struct: GroupGenerators] [Serialization attack] Can malicious validators deserialize GroupGenerators with identity elements or low-order points, bypassing cryptographic security assumptions and enabling signature forgery? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Struct: GroupGenerators] [Small subgroup attack] Are the generators validated to be in the prime-order subgroup after deserialization, or can an attacker provide generators in small subgroups to break discrete log security? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: powers_of_two()] [Memory exhaustion] Can an attacker cause DoS by requesting an extremely large `ell` value (e.g., usize::MAX), forcing allocation of massive vectors and exhausting node memory? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: powers_of_two()] [Incorrect computation] Does the function handle ell >= 64 correctly, or will bit shifts beyond field size produce incorrect results that break cryptographic protocols relying on these powers? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: commit_to_scalars()] [Point at infinity] Can an attacker provide commitment_base as the point at infinity, causing all commitments to be zero regardless of scalars, breaking binding properties? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: commit_to_scalars()] [Low-order base point] If commitment_base is in a small subgroup, can an attacker recover scalars via small-subgroup attacks, breaking commitment hiding properties? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: commit_to_scalars()] [Timing side-channel] Does scalar multiplication leak timing information about scalar values through variable-time operations, allowing attackers to extract secret shares or keys? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: scalar_to_u32()] [Truncation vulnerability] Can an attacker provide a scalar larger than u32::MAX that gets truncated to None, but is still used in downstream code expecting a valid value, causing state corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: scalar_to_u32()] [Endianness attack] Does the little-endian to_bytes_le() conversion match the expected byte order in all protocol contexts, or can endianness mismatches cause different validators to compute different u32 values? [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: scalar_to_u32()] [Negative value handling] For prime fields with modulus close to 2^256, can negative representations or values > 2^32 bypass the length check and cause incorrect conversions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/src/arkworks/mod.rs] [Function: compute_roots_of_unity()] [Invalid domain size] Can an attacker provide num_omegas that's not a power of two, causing expect() to panic and crash the validator node during consensus? (High)
